questions.text: Who is considered as Father of Modern Psychiatry?
questions.solution: PHILIPPE PINEL is considered as Father of Modern Psychiatry and introduced a human approach to Psychiatry by 'Unchaining of patients'. Option B - coined the term 'Psychiatry'. Option C - Father of Psychoanalysis and Option D - Founder of EEG

questions.text: Medically speaking, mania is defined as...
questions.solution:
Mania is defined as an abnormally elevated mood state characterized by such symptoms as inappropriate elation, increased irritability, severe insomnia, grandiose notions, increased speed and/or volume of speech, disconnected and racing thoughts, increased sexual desire, markedly increased energy and activity level, poor judgment, and inappropriate social behavior.

Note: Mania is the Greek word for madness.

questions.text: First Rank Symptoms in Schizophrenia were put forth by:
questions.solution: KURT SCHNEIDER is related to First Rank Symptoms in Schiz. Option A- coined term 'Schizophrenia' meaning split mind. Option C - split mental illness into Dementia Praecox and Manic Depressive Psychosis. Option D - proposed a theory that Schizophrenia is more likely associated with Asthenic (Thin built) habitus individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in '4 As of Bleuler'?
questions.solution: ANHEDONIA is a cardinal symptom of Depression. The term implies inability to experience pleasure and was coined by Ribot.

choices.text: Voices arguing or discussing about the patient among themselves
Voice giving running commentary about the patients
Hearing one's own thoughts spoken aloud

questions.text: NOT a First Rank Symptom of Schizophrenia
questions.solution: They are 3rd person, 2nd person, 1st person Auditory Hallucinations respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following Antidepressant is LEAST LIKELY to cause sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution: BUPROPION is an antidepressant belonging to class NDRI. It is not likely to cause sexual dysfunction. Option B is an SNRI and options C and D are SSRIs. They have long term side effect of Sexual Dysfunction which is reversible and due to modulation of Serotonin.

questions.text: A patient on Cancer Chemotherapy has developed depression and troublesome nausea, loss of appetite and sleep disturbance. Which among the following antidepressants would you prefer?
questions.solution:
MIRTAZAPINE is preferred in view of its sedation, appetite enhancing (H1 blocking), Anti-nausea effects (5HT3 antagonism) along with its effect on serotonergic neurotransmission.

Watch for orthostatic hypotension, anticholinergic effects like dry mouth, weight gain (which is good in this case), Blood counts, LFT and Lipid profile.

questions.text: A Psychiatrist plans to give a combination of Antidepressant for a diagnosis of Treatment Resistant Depression. Which of the following combination is most likely to produce adverse effects among the following?
questions.solution:
Combination of SSRI or SNRI with a Monoamine oxidase Inhibitor like Tranylcypromine can sometimes produce more serious interactions with features of Serotonin Syndrome.

Others may produce certain side effects but are not contraindicated. Choice A may be utilized in a patient on Fluoxetine who developed Sexual dysfunction. Choice D is tried in Resistant Depression as a combination strategy and is known as 'California Rocket fuel'.

questions.text: Dysfunctional events that occur during the sleep is called as:
questions.solution: Dysfunctional events in sleep and option A refers to conditions that impair quantity of sleep - which includes Insomnia and Hypersomnia

questions.text: A pregnant lady on mood stabilizer for Bipolar disorder later delivered a baby who was cyanotic and in respiratory distress at birth. Echo revealed displacement of tricuspid into ventricle and s/o Ebstein's Anomaly. Which of the following Mood stabilizer is most likely to be the culprit of this teratogenic effect?
questions.solution: LITHIUM is associated with the teratogenic effect of Ebstein's Anomaly.

questions.text: During De addiction ward rounds, the therapist asked the patient admitted as multiple episodes of Alcohol withdrawal seizures about 'What he think of his drinking'. The patient replied that 'I just drink occasionally and is not addict. I will stop later when I feel'. At what stage of Change is he?
questions.solution: In this phase of Prochaska and Dclemente model, the individual does not consider his behavior as a problem and do not consider any need for change.

questions.text: Which of the following Antipsychotics among the following is most likely to cause Prolactin elevation?
questions.solution: Amisulpride among Second generation Antipsychotics and the First generation Antipsychotics are more likely to cause Hyperprolactinemia. Other drugs in the list are less likely to elevate prolactin than these drugs.

questions.text: Partial agonist of Dopaminergic Receptors is seen in:
questions.solution: ARIPIPRAZOLE, Cariprazine, Brexpiprazole are sometimes called as 'Third generation Antipsychotics'. They have features of partial dopaminergic agonism. Option C is newer Antipsychotic for Psychotic symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients and act by 5HT2Ainverse agonist.

questions.text: A 68 yr old male was brought to casualty as seizures and there is evidence of Hyponatremia. He is on mood stabilizer for Bipolar Disorder. Which of the following is most likely cause?
questions.solution: OXCARBAZEPINE is most likely to cause Hyponatremia. Valproate in higher doses has reports of hyponatremia but not as common as choice C. Option B has no documented effects on electrolyte and Option D cause Diabetes insipidus

questions.text: Which of the following is a Sensory Distortion?
questions.solution:
Disorders of perception can be broadly Sensory Distortion and Sensory Deception. In Sensory Distortion, there is a real perceivable stimulus but it appears to be change in intensity or quality to the observer. It may appear small (option A) or larger than it is (option B) or even farther than it is (option C).

Sensory Deception examples are ILLUSIONS and HALLUCINATIONS

questions.text: Attention is tested by :
questions.solution: DIGIT SPAN TEST is used for test of Attention. Option A is test for sustained attention (Concentration). Option B tests recent memory while Option D is a test for Test

choices.text: Sudden spasmodic contraction of agonist-antagonist muscle
Tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia and slurred speech
Uncontrollable oro facial chewing or lip smacking movements

questions.text: Most common Extrapyramidal side effect of Antipsychotics is:
questions.solution: SUBJECTIVE AND OBJECTIVE RESTLESNESS which is known as AKATHISIA. Option A is Dystonia, which is earliest side effect to appear. Option C is Pseudo Parkinsonism and Option D is Tardive Dyskinesia

questions.text: A patient is found comatose, with myoclonic twitching and his serum Lithium was found to be 4.2 mEq/L. For best response which of the following should be Initiated?
questions.solution: HEMODIALYSIS is required in this case of Severe Lithium Toxicity and requires rapid removal from Body. There is no antidote for Lithium.

questions.text: A 48 yr old man has been referred to you for consideration of starting Antipsychotics for Schizophrenia. He is obese, with metabolic syndrome and has family History of sudden cardiac death. Which of the following drug is most suited for him?
questions.solution: ARIPIRAZOLE is weight neutral and no QT prolongation. Hence it is best option in this case.

questions.text: Compared to other causes of Dementia, early presentation in Creutzfeldt - Jacob disease more often includes:
questions.solution: Option A in FTD/Pick's disease, option C in Parkinson's /DLB, Option D in Huntington's disease.

questions.text: Most common side effect associated with Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors are:
questions.solution: NAUSEA AND GASTRITIS - GI side effects are most common with SSRI drugs.

questions.text: Parents of a 5 year old boy brought the child to clinic with complaint of frequent awakening during night screaming and looks terrified. There are also signs of autonomic hyperactivity. When awaken in next day morning, he has no recall of the event. This is most consistent with :
questions.solution: PAVOR NOCTURNUS or Night terror or Sleep Terror is a NREM phenomenon and child has no recall of In Nightmare, which is a REM sleep phenomenon, the subject has recall of events.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT CORRECTLY MATCHED side effect of drugs used in Deaddiction?
questions.solution: TOPIRAMATE has NEPHROLITHIASIS as side effect. Rest all are correctly matched.

questions.text: Disulfiram is Aldehyde Dehydrogenase inhibitor used as an aversive agent in Alcohol dependent individuals. How long an individual on Disulfiram should has to wait after stopping the drug to be sure that he won't be experiencing unpleasant side effects on resuming alcohol consumption?
questions.solution: 7-14 DAYS after stopping the drug. The effect of drug lasts for 7-14 days and hence even after stopping the drug, the subject may experience Disulfiram ethanol reaction if he consumes alcohol in this period.

choices.text: First line of management is intravenous Dexamethasone infusion
Severe Anterograde amnesia with variable retrograde Amnesia seen in Korsakoff's syndrome
Triad of Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia, Global confusion is seen in 90% cases
History of Withdrawal seizure is essential for Diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding Wernicke Korsakoff Syndrome?
questions.solution: First line management is intravenous Thiamine infusion. Only one-third or less present with classical triad.

choices.text: Alcohol Dependence is suspected if AUDIT score less than 12
AUDIT- C is a short version scale of 3 questions

questions.text: Identify the WRONG statement about AUDIT scale used for evaluation of Alcohol use Disorder
questions.solution: ALCOHOL Dependence is suspected with AUDIT is score is above 13 in women or 15 in men

choices.text: Increase the chance of Motor Neuropathy
Increase severity of Disulfiram Ethanol reaction

questions.text: The combination of Naltrexone and Disulfiram should be used with caution because:
questions.solution: BOTH ARE POTENTIALLY HEAPTOTOXIC as they are metabolized by liver

choices.text: Glutamate down regulation - leading to neuronal hyper excitability
Glutamate up regulation - leading to neuronal hyper excitability
GABA down regulation - leading to neuronal inhibition
GABA up regulation - leading to neuronal hyper excitability

questions.text: Most accurate biological explanation for development of Alcohol withdrawal syndrome is:
questions.solution: there is UPREGULATION of GLUTAMATE and DOWN REGULATION of GABA both leading to NEURONAL HYPEREXCITABILITY

choices.text: No Thiamine required as no evident Wernicke's signs
Thiamine 500mg 3 times daily intramuscularly x 5 days
Thiamine 100mg orally 3 times daily x 1 week
Thiamine 500mg intravenous 3 times daily x 5 days

questions.text: A severely malnourished patient with long history of alcohol dependence is admitted to hospital for surgery. He develops withdrawal delirium. He has no signs of Wernicke's encephalopathy. Which is the best strategy in Thiamine replacement?
questions.solution: Alcohol dependent subjects are highly likely to be nutritionally depleted in vitamins and minerals and hence should be supplemented. Thiamine in particular should be supplemented for the risk of development of Wernicke’s. Thiamine is required in carbohydrate metabolism and deficiency should be anticipated in a malnourished alcohol user and also regarding increase in his requirement as we provide carbohydrate replenishing or supplementation.

choices.text: It is a GABA-B receptor Agonist
Usual therapeutic dose for anti-craving effect is 150 to 200mg/day
Safe to use in Alcohol Liver disease
Pedal edema and increased urination frequency are reported side effects

questions.text: BACLOFEN, a muscle relaxant is used in Alcohol use Disorder. Which of the following is NOT true about Baclofen?
questions.solution: From 30mg/day to 300mg/day doses have been tried for Alcohol related cravings

questions.text: Which of the following Psychiatric disorder occur as most common comorbidity along with Anorexia Nervosa?
questions.solution: MAJOR DEPRESIVE DISORDER is the most common comorbidity associated

questions.text: Which of the following cognitive functions is most likely to remain stable with Aging?
questions.solution: Syntax, vocabulary, communication and store of knowledge are likely to remain normal with aging. All other functions listed tend to decline with age.

questions.text: Ventral tegmental area, Nucleus Accumbens and prefrontal cortex are all major pathways involved in :
questions.solution: This is the Reward Pathway with Dopamine as major neurotransmitter involved in Addiction.

questions.text: Compared to young adults , Elderly people require lower doses of Lithium to achieve a given lithium concentration because:
questions.solution: REDUCED RENALCLEARANCE in Elderly helps to achieve higher serum levels with lower doses in elderly. There is not hepatic metabolism for Lithium

questions.text: A 39 yr. old office secretary is reported to be too much strict in matters of time keeping, rules and policies. He is not ready to compromise and is considered 'adamant and inflexible, intolerant' to other's mistake. He follows his own strict plans and will never agree to or consider other's suggestions even if worth considerable. When told about this he says 'Those lazy people may say nonsense. What I say is actually correct. They don't like my strictness and hence complain'. This can be best described as:
questions.solution: The patient in question is likely to be Anankastic personality Disorder. To the individual, all these appear normal and 'nothing wrong' because it goes along with his wishes, plans, and beliefs and is not able to recognize it as a problem. This is known as 'Ego syntonic'.

questions.text: Which of the following gene-chromosome combination in Alzheimer's disease is INCORRECTLY matched?
questions.solution: APP GENE is located in CHROMOSOME 21.

questions.text: Term 'CATASTROPHIC REACTION' was coined by:
questions.solution: GOLDSTEIN used this terminology in subjects with Dementing illness in their initial stages demonstrate emotional outbursts and distress when they start realizing their deficits consequences of change from previous functioning.

questions.text: Odd and eccentric behavior, unusual perceptions, constricted affect, fantasy mannerisms all fit into which personality disorder?
questions.solution: SCHIZOTYPAL features.

questions.text: Your friend developed a panic attack while travelling along with you in a bus. He showed you the medications with him, which he used to take for diagnosis of Panic Disorder, but now stopped since 2 months. Which among the following in the list if available will you ask him to take immediately, considering it as Panic attack?
questions.solution: ALPRAZOLAM is a Benzodiazepine and is used in acute attacks and faster action.

questions.text: Proponent of CLIENT CENTERED PSYCHOTHERAPY is:
questions.solution: Option A-Rational Emotive Therapy, option B - Cognitive Behavior Therapy and option C - Operant conditioning

questions.text: As per Sigmund Freud Psychosexual stages of Development, Electra complex is seen in :
questions.solution: FEMALE in Phallic Phase 3-5 yrs. Electra complex is 'a girl & rsquo;s psychosexual competition with her mother for possession of her father' and is a terminology in Neo-Freudian Psychology

questions.text: A dystonic reaction characterized by tonic, flexion on one side accompanied by slight rotation without other dystonic reaction, that may develop as an adverse effect of Antipsychotic is:
questions.solution: Option A is orofacial movements that develops in Antipsychotic use. Option C is Delusion of Infidelity and option D is obesity, hyperventilation and sleep apnea.

questions.text: 'Stop-Start' technique and 'squeeze technique' are useful in:
Respiratory Depression, hypothermia, pin point pupil, coma/altered sensorium are all seen in:
Which of the following medical conditions can produce Depression?
questions.solution: ALL OF THE ABOVE can be etiology of Depression

questions.text: Propranolol is useful in :
questions.solution: It is useful in management of Lithium and Valproate induced Tremor

questions.text: Among the following drugs, Thyroid dysfunction is LEAST associated with :
questions.solution: An SSRI is least likely to affect thyroid function. Choice A and B are associated and requires monitoring. Choice C can also induce autoimmune thyroiditis as per reports.

choices.text: Deficiency of Hypoxanthine Guanine Phosphoribosyl Transferase enzyme implicated
Molecular genetic testing of HPRT1 gene mutation aid in Diagnosis

questions.text: On evaluating a male child with Intellectual disability and involuntary writhing movement of arms and legs, the clinician noticed self-mutilation behavior and lab parameters suggestive of Kidney function impairment and hyperuricemia. NOT True regarding this :
questions.solution:
It is an inborn error of PURINE METABOLISM.

It is LESCH NYHAN SYNDROME and a cause of Intellectual Disability.

questions.text: With the use of Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors, Cheese reaction is mainly associated with:
questions.solution: TYRAMINE accumulation occurs as the inhibition of enzyme that degrades Tyramine, results in Hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: The term 'Inferiority Complex' was contributed by:
questions.solution: Option A is Father of Psychoanalysis, Option B is related to Transactional Analysis, Option C is related to Client centered Therapy and Interpersonal Therapy.
